standard_metadata.standard_description: An angle is measured with reference to a circle with its center at the common endpoint of the rays, by considering the fraction of the circular arc between the points where the two rays intersect the circle. An angle that turns through 1/360 of a circle is called a “one-degree angle,” and can be used to measure angles.

question.content: Look at the circle below. $\angle{NOP}$ is $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of a full turn.    **How many degrees does $\angle{NOP}$ measure?**

images.alt: A circle with center point O and two rays. Ray ON points to 9 o'clock. Ray OP points to 3 o’clock.

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
$\angle{NOP}$ is equal to $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of a turn.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into two equal parts that are labeled one-half. Two black lines show angle NOP comprising one-half of the circle.

hints.content: $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of a turn is equal to $180\degree$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into two equal parts that are labeled 180 degrees. Two black lines show angle NOP comprising 180 degrees of the circle.

hints.content: $\angle{NOP}$ measure is $180$ degrees.

question.content: Look at the circle below. $\angle{ABC}$ is $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of a full turn.    **How many degrees does $\angle{ABC}$ measure?**

images.alt: A circle with center point B and two rays. Ray BC points to 5 o'clock. Ray BA points to 9 o’clock.

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
$\angle{ABC}$ is equal to $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of a turn.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into three equal parts that are labeled one-third. Two black lines show angle ABC comprising one-third of the circle.

hints.content: $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of a turn is equal to $120\degree$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into three equal parts that are labeled 120 degrees. Two black lines show angle ABC comprising 120 degrees of the circle.

hints.content: $\angle{ABC}$ is $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of a full turn, so its measure is $120$ degrees.

question.content: Look at the circle below. $\angle{XYZ}$ is $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a full turn.    **How many degrees does $\angle{XYZ}$ measure?**

images.alt: A circle with center point Y and two rays. Ray YX points to 9 o'clock. Ray YZ points to 6 o'clock.

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
$\angle{XYZ}$ is equal to $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a turn.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into four equal parts that are labeled one-fourth. Two black lines show angle XYZ comprising one-fourth of the circle.

hints.content: $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a turn is equal to $90\degree$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into four equal parts that are labeled 90 degrees. Two black lines show angle XYZ comprising 90 degrees of the circle.

hints.content: $\angle{XYZ}$ is $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a full turn, so its measure is $90$ degrees.

question.content: Look at the circle below. $\angle{RST}$ is $\dfrac{1}{6}$ of a full turn.    **How many degrees does $\angle{RST}$ measure?**

images.alt: A circle divided into four equal parts with angle RST comprising about two-thirds of a section.

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
$\angle{RST}$ is equal to $\dfrac{1}{6}$ of a turn.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into six equal parts that are labeled one-sixth. Two black lines show angle RST comprising one-sixth of the circle.

hints.content: $\dfrac{1}{6}$ of a turn is equal to $60\degree$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into six equal parts that are labeled 60 degrees. Two black lines show angle RST comprising 60 degrees of the circle.

hints.content: $\angle{RST}$ is $\dfrac{1}{6}$ of a full turn, so its measure is $60$ degrees.

question.content: Look at the circle below. $\angle{DEF}$ is $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of a full turn.    **How many degrees does $\angle{DEF}$ measure?**

images.alt: A circle with center point E and two rays. Ray EF points to between 11 and 12 o'clock, slightly closer to 11 o'clock. Ray ED points to between 12 and 1 o'clock, slightly closer to 1 o'clock.

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
$\angle{DEF}$ is equal to $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of a turn.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into eight equal parts that are labeled one-eighth. Two black lines show angle DEF comprising one-eighth of the circle.

hints.content: $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of a turn is equal to $45\degree$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into eight equal parts that are labeled 45 degrees. Two black lines show angle DEF comprising 45 degrees of the circle.

hints.content: $\angle{DEF}$ is $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of a full turn, so its measure is $45$ degrees.

question.content: Look at the circle below. $\angle{ABC}$ is $\dfrac{1}{12}$ of a full turn.    **How many degrees does $\angle{ABC}$ measure?**

images.alt: A circle with center point B and two rays. Ray BC points to 9 o'clock. Ray BA points to 10 o’clock.

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
$\angle{ABC}$ is equal to $\dfrac{1}{12}$ of a turn.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into twelve equal parts that are labeled one-twelfth. Two black lines show angle ABC comprising one-twelfth of the circle.

hints.content: $\dfrac{1}{12}$ of a turn is equal to $30\degree$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into twelve equal parts that are labeled 30 degrees. Two black lines show angle ABC comprising 30 degrees of the circle.

hints.content: $\angle{ABC}$ is $\dfrac{1}{12}$ of a full turn, so its measure is $30$ degrees.

question.content: **How many $30\degree$ angles does it take to make a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.  How many $30$'s are in $360$?

images.alt: A circle divided into 12 equal parts each labeled 30 degrees.

hints.content: It takes twelve $30\degree$ angles to make a full turn.

question.content: **How many $45\degree$ angles does it take to make a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.  How many $45$'s are in $360$?

images.alt: A circle divided into 8 equal parts each labeled 45 degrees.

hints.content: It takes eight $45\degree$ angles to make a full turn.

question.content: **How many $60\degree$ angles does it take to make a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.  How many $60$'s are in $360$?

images.alt: A circle divided into 6 equal parts each labeled 60 degrees.

hints.content: It takes six $60\degree$ angles to make a full turn.

question.content: **How many $90\degree$ angles does it take to make a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.  How many $90$'s are in $360$?

images.alt: A circle divided into 4 equal parts each labeled 90 degrees.

hints.content: It takes four $90\degree$ angles to make a full turn.

question.content: **How many $120\degree$ angles does it take to make a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.  How many $120$'s are in $360$?

images.alt: A circle divided into 3 equal parts each labeled 120 degrees.

hints.content: It takes three $120\degree$ angles to make a full turn.

question.content: **How many $180\degree$ angles does it take to make a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.  How many $180$'s are in $360$?

images.alt: A circle divided into 2 equal parts each labeled 180 degrees.

hints.content: It takes two $180\degree$ angles to make a full turn.

question.content: **How many $360\degree$ angles does it take to make a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.  How many $360$'s are in $360$?

images.alt: A circle consists of 1 part labeled 360 degrees.

hints.content: It takes one $360\degree$ angle to make a full turn.

question.content: **How many degrees are in $\dfrac12$ of a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
To find a *half* of something, we divide by $2$.  $360 \div 2 = 180$  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into halves. Each half is labeled 180 degrees.

hints.content: There are $180\degree$ in a half of a turn.

question.content: **How many degrees are in  $\dfrac13$ of a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
To find a *third* of something, we divide by $3$.  $360 \div 3 = 120$  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into thirds. Each third is labeled 120 degrees.

hints.content: There are $120\degree$ in a third of a turn.

question.content: **How many degrees are in a quarter of a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
To find a *quarter* of something, we divide by $4$.  $360 \div 4 = 90$  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into fourths. Each fourth is labeled 90 degrees. The angles in the center of the circle each have a box representing a right angle.

hints.content: There are $90\degree$ in a quarter of a turn.

question.content: **How many degrees are in  $\dfrac16$ of a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
To find a *sixth* of something, we divide by $6$.  $360 \div 6 = 60$   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into sixths. Each sixth is labeled 60 degrees.

hints.content: There are $60\degree$ in a sixth of a turn.

question.content: **How many degrees are in  $\dfrac18$ of a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
To find a *eighth* of something, we divide by $8$.  $360 \div 8 = 45$   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into eighths. Each eighth is labeled 45 degrees.

hints.content: There are $45\degree$ in an eighth of a turn.

question.content: **How many degrees are in $\dfrac1{12}$ of a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
To find a *twelfth* of something, we divide by $12$.  $360 \div 12 = 30$   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into twelfths. Each twelfth is labeled 30 degrees.

hints.content: There are $30\degree$ in a twelfth of a turn.

question.content: **How many degrees are in $\dfrac34$ of a full turn?**

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$.
To find a *fourth* of something, we divide by $4$.  $360 \div 4 = 90$  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle divided into fourths. Each fourth is labeled 90 degrees.

hints.content: So, $\dfrac34$ of something is equal to $90\degree$ three times.  $90\times3=270$
There are $270\degree$ in $\dfrac34$ of a turn.

question.content: The circle is divided into $360$ equal parts. Point $X$ represents the center of the circle.    **Which angle measures $45\degree$?**

images.alt: A circle with center point X and four rays. Ray XV points halfway between 5 and 6 o'clock. Ray XW points to 1 o'clock. Ray XY points halfway between 11 and 12 o'clock. Ray XZ points halfway between 8 and 9 o'clock.

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$ around the center.  [[☃ image 1]]  How much of a turn is $45\degree$?

images.alt: A circle with center point X and 360 equally spaced marks around its outside edge.

hints.content: $45\degree$ is $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of a turn.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle with center point X, showing that angle WXY takes up one-eighth of the circle.

hints.content: So, angle $WXY$ measures $45\degree$.

question.content: The circle is divided into $360$ equal parts. Point $A$ represents the center of the circle.    **Which angle measures $90\degree$?**

images.alt: A circle with center point A and four rays. Ray AE points halfway between 8 and 9 o'clock. Ray AD points halfway between 11 and 12 o'clock. Ray AC points halfway between 1 and 2 o'clock. Ray AB points halfway between 2 and 3 o'clock.

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$ around the center.  [[☃ image 1]]  How much of a turn is $90\degree$?

images.alt: A circle with center point A and 360 equally spaced marks around its outside edge.

hints.content: $90\degree$ is a $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a turn.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle with center point A, showing that angle EAD takes up one-fourth of the circle.

hints.content: So, the measure of angle $EAD$ is $90\degree$.

question.content: The circle is divided into $360$ equal parts. Point $O$ represents the center of the circle.    **Which angle measures $70\degree$?**

images.alt: A circle with center point O and four rays. Ray OL points to 9 o'clock. Ray OM points to slightly before 10 o'clock. Ray ON points to 12 o'clock. Ray OP points to 3 o'clock.

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$ around the center.  [[☃ image 1]]  How much of a turn is $70\degree$?

images.alt: A circle with center point O and 360 equally spaced marks around its outside edge.

hints.content: $70\degree$ is a little less than $90\degree$. So $70\degree$ is a little less than $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a turn.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle with center point O, showing that angle MON takes up slightly less than one-fourth of the circle.

hints.content: So, the measure of angle $MON$ is $70\degree$.

question.content: The circle is divided into $360$ equal parts. Point $A$ represents the center of the circle.    **Which angle measures $105\degree$?**

images.alt: A circle with center point A and four rays. Ray AE points halfway between 11 and 12 o'clock. Ray AD points to 12 o'clock. Ray AC points halfway between 1 and 2 o'clock. Ray AB points to 3 o'clock.

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$ around the center.    [[☃ image 1]]  How much of a turn is $105\degree$?

images.alt: A circle with center point A and 360 equally spaced marks around its outside edge.

hints.content: $105\degree$ is a little more than $90\degree$. So $105\degree$ is a little more than $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a turn.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle with center point A, showing that angle EAB takes up a little more than one-fourth of the circle.

hints.content: So, the measure of angle $BAE$ is $105\degree$.

question.content: The circle is divided into $360$ equal parts. Point $O$ represents the center of the circle.    **Which angle measures $120\degree$?**

images.alt: A circle with center point O and four rays. Ray OL points halfway between 3 and 4 o'clock. Ray OM points to 2 o'clock. Ray ON points to 12 o'clock. Ray OP points to 8 o'clock.

hints.content: A full turn is $360\degree$ around the center.  [[☃ image 1]]  How much of a turn is $120\degree$?

images.alt: A circle with center point O and 360 equally spaced marks around its outside edge.

hints.content: $120\degree$ is a $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of a turn.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A circle with center point O, showing that angle NOP takes up one-third of the circle.

hints.content: So, the measure of angle $NOP$ is $120\degree$.
